title: U.S. Trade Deficit in Goods Hits Record
summary: The shortfall grew last year despite President Trump's aim to reduce it. WASHINGTON-The U.S. trade deficit in goods hit a record in 2018, defying President Trump's efforts to narrow the gap, as imports jumped and some exports, including soybeans and other farm products, got hammered by retaliation against U.S. trade policies.

title: White House Presses Businesses to Reshape Training Efforts
summary: Ivanka Trump convenes new workforce-policy group; 'we don't have people to fill the jobs'. WASHINGTON-U.S. employers need to enhance workers' skills for the economy to remain on its robust growth trajectory, White House officials said while gathering with business leaders, educators and governors to discuss the need to pull more Americans into the workforce and prepare them for jobs.

title: U.S. Dollar Rises Against Canadian Currency
summary: A warning by Canada's central bank weighs on that nation's currency. The U.S. dollar rose Wednesday, boosted by gains against Canada's currency after the Bank of Canada said the global economic slowdown last year was more extensive than it forecast in January.

title: Florida Contractor Seeks Bankruptcy Deal Over Fatal Bridge Collapse
summary: Magnum Construction Management will participate in victim mediation. The contractor for a pedestrian bridge at Florida International University that collapsed is plotting a return to the construction business while negotiating a bankruptcy settlement fund for those killed or injured in the accident.

title: Muni Bonds Enjoy Historic Run Despite Tax Overhaul
summary: Investors this year have poured the most money into municipal bond funds in at least 13 years. Municipal bonds are enjoying their strongest start to a year since at least 2006, defying expectations that President Trump's sweeping tax overhaul would depress demand in the market.

title: Trump Administration Looks to Jump Start Interstate Health-Insurance Sales
summary: Past efforts to sell policies across state lines have gained little traction. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is weighing new ways to spur the sale of health insurance across state lines, a long-held goal of President Trump and congressional Republicans that has so far failed to gain much traction.

title: Walmart Toughens Delivery Demands for Suppliers
summary: Looking to cut inventory while meeting e-commerce demands, the retailer wants more of the goods it orders delivered on time and in full. Walmart Inc. is raising its delivery goal posts for suppliers, asking them to deliver more goods on time as it competes with Amazon.com Inc. for shoppers online and in stores.

title: Unleash the Bots: Firms Report Positive Returns With RPA
summary: Early adopters of robotic process automation report higher productivity, happier customers, but it is still early days. Companies using software robots to automate repetitive, mundane and rules-based tasks report that they are seeing payoff in various ways, according to a new study.

title: 'Jeopardy!' Host Alex Trebek Says He Has Pancreatic Cancer
summary: Longtime quiz show host discloses illness directly to fans in online video. LOS ANGELES-Jeopardy!" host Alex Trebek says he has been diagnosed with advanced pancreatic cancer.

title: Private Schools Sue Over New York's Push to Increase Oversight
summary: New York State Association of Independent Schools filed suit on behalf of its 192 members. New York's private schools have filed a lawsuit to halt the state's efforts to expand oversight of their academics, saying it overstepped its authority.

title: Baton, Successor to Bankrate, Pays $28 Million to Settle Accounting Fraud Case
summary: Successor to financial marketing firm admitted that former executives inflated earnings. A successor to financial services and marketing company Bankrate Inc. agreed to pay $28 million to settle a federal investigation into accounting fraud by former executives, the U.S. Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: Should We Need a Nudge to Be Free People?
summary: Richard Epstein's review of Cass Sunstein's "On Freedom" incisively frames the dichotomy between the classical liberal and today's progressive.. Richard Epstein's review of Cass Sunstein's "On Freedom" ("Nudged To Be Free," Bookshelf, Feb. 28) incisively frames the dichotomy between the classical liberal and today's progressive. Sixty years ago the eminent political theorist Isaiah Berlin put the question even more starkly in a 1958 Oxford lecture (and subsequent essay) called "Two Concepts of Liberty." On the one hand, he said, there's real liberty, where people are free to make their own decisions. On the other, there's false liberty, where people are "nudged" to do what is decided is best for them. The fallacy inherent in this approach is first, as Mr. Epstein asks, who does the nudging? Can those who are convinced they know what's best for you be that certain they are right? No, said Berlin. Even with the best of intentions, they cannot.

title: Reboot Microsoft's Geeks' Military Cold Feet
summary: I switched to Microsoft Edge from Google Chrome last year after a similar kerfuffle at Google. I may soon be switching back to Safari.. In "The Geeks vs. the Infantrymen" (op-ed, Feb. 27), Maj. Gen. Robert H. Scales makes a solid case that Microsoft ideologues foolishly attack the Integrated Visual Augmentation System (IVAS), which well may save the lives of their friends and relatives on future battlefields. I served as an infantryman and NCO during the Korean conflict and as an artillery officer during the Vietnam War. Surely in strategic planning-modifications and modernization of tactics, individual and unit training, weapons systems, communications and transportation-there are myraid opportunities to create superior infantry forces that suffer fewer casualties while inflicting more on the enemy. It will take IVAS and a whole lot more improvements and breakthroughs to reduce casualties and win conflicts.

title: Even Obama Was Dinged For Stressing Personal Responsibility
summary: Regarding Jason L. Riley's "The Media Wanted to Believe Jussie Smollett": Identity politics and victimization offer to everyone the comforting illusion that the disappointments and hurts of life are someone else's fault.. Regarding Jason L. Riley's "The Media Wanted to Believe Jussie Smollett" (Upward Mobility, Feb. 27): Identity politics and victimization offer to everyone the comforting illusion that the disappointments and hurts of life are someone else's fault, and not the result of bad luck or one's own faults and weaknesses. If you are a woman, the cause of bad outcomes is sexism. If black or Hispanic, it is racism. If gay, it is homophobia. If you are a straight, white male (the villain of identity politics), it is reverse discrimination.

title: Hillary Clinton's 'Win' and That 2016 Popular Vote
summary: The final vote tally in that election was 65,849,610 for Mrs. Clinton, 71,224,666 for someone else.. William A. Galston disserves our hard-won constitutional form by claiming Hillary Clinton "enjoy[ed] a popular-vote margin of nearly three million," suggesting once again that somehow she "won" the 2016 election but was robbed because of a flawed Electoral College system he wishes replaced ("Two Ways Democrats Can Win in 2020," Politics & Ideas, Feb. 27).

title: Nicolás Maduro Has Ruthless Allies Who Will Help Him Survive in Power
summary: Bashar al-Assad survived due to Russia, Iran and other bad actors and his willingness to brutally crush the Syrian people. Cuba, Russia (and probably China) will do the same in Venezuela.. Regarding Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Maduro and Cuba Lose" (Americas, Feb. 25): Years ago, Ms. O'Grady's analysis would be correct; post-Syria, however, it is not. Bashar al-Assad survived due to Russia, Iran and other bad actors and his willingness to brutally crush the Syrian people. Cuba, Russia (and probably China) will strengthen Nicolás Maduro's will and enable his torture of Venezuelans, pushing aside U.S. attempts to change the situation. Russia, China, et al., rigorously enforce their alleged "sphere of influence" and beyond. The U.S. doesn't even mention the Monroe Doctrine.

title: Private Is the New Social for Facebook
summary: Mark Zuckerberg said private communications will be just as important as public ones for Facebook. Facebook , like most social-media platforms, is free to use. Increasingly, though, users say even that is too high a price to pay for their privacy.

title: Senate Confirms Justice Department Lawyer to Federal Appeals Court
summary: Democrats objected to lawyer's role in Trump decision to stop defending parts of Affordable Care Act. WASHINGTON-A divided Senate confirmed a top Justice Department lawyer to be a federal appeals judge Wednesday, over objections about his participation in the Trump administration's decision to stop defending major parts of the Affordable Care Act in court.

title: Republicans, Democrats and 'Decent' Guys
summary: Are any 2020 candidates interested in civility?. Former Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz says he's considering an independent run for President to counter what he calls the "revenge politics" practiced by two bitterly divided political parties. The liberal Mr. Schultz has been excoriated on the left because many Democratic activists believe, perhaps mistakenly, that he would inadvertently help President Donald Trump get re-elected.

title: Senators Decry Saudi Human Rights Abuses
summary: Crown prince has gone 'full gangster,' becoming an untenable ally, says Sen. Marco Rubio. WASHINGTON-Senators on Wednesday warned that Saudi Arabia is committing a growing list of rights abuses, citing the detention and alleged torture of a U.S.-Saudi physician, adding to pressure on the Trump administration to reconsider its close ties to the country's rulers.

title: Fed's About-Face Hits Short-Term Bond Investments
summary: Short-term debt exchange-traded funds have seen two consecutive months of outflows. Investors are liquidating their investments in funds that own some of the safest short-term debt and buying stocks and longer-term bonds, yet another sign that the dovish stance by central bankers is stoking appetite for risk.

title: Health Venture of Amazon, Berkshire, JPMorgan Has a Name: Haven
summary: Venture isn't meant to generate profits and will 'reinvest any surplus back into our work'. The high-profile health-care venture launched last year by Amazon.com Inc., Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and JPMorgan Chase & Co. finally has a name: Haven.

title: Trudeau Confidant Defends Embattled Government
summary: Gerald Butts offers full-throated defense against accusations of improper push to shield Montreal firm from prosecution. OTTAWA-One of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's closest confidants said Wednesday the leader's office did nothing untoward in suggesting last year that the then-justice minister review a criminal prosecution against an important Montreal engineering firm at the center of a political crisis.

title: Connecticut Gov. Lamont Pitches Highway Tolls
summary: State's special transportation fund faces a deficit in the fiscal year 2023. Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont and a coalition of business leaders, labor officials and lawmakers called Wednesday for the establishment of highway tolls as a way to pay for upgrades to the state's crumbling transportation system.

title: 'Between Worlds: The Art of Bill Traylor' Review: A Master's Discerning, Yet Untrained, Eye
summary: Bill Traylor's gesticulating men, imposing women, agile animals and evocations of a hard rural life are all drawn with spectacular economy and animation, almost always with wit and humor..

title: 'Captain Marvel' Review: Woman but No Wonder
summary: Brie Larson stars in the female-focused epic that's heavy on action but light on saving graces.. It takes a long time for "Captain Marvel" to focus its force fields, and for Brie Larson's dauntless pilot, Carol Danvers, to find her true identity, her authentic superpowers and a reason we should care about her convoluted adventures.

title: U.S. Stocks Continue to Slide
summary: Indexes decline for third straight session ahead of update on trade, Friday's jobs report. U.S. stocks fell for a third consecutive session Wednesday, closing at their lowest level in three weeks as analysts looked ahead to Friday's jobs report and sought an update on global trade policy.

title: Homeland Chief Defends Trump's Declaration of Border Emergency
summary: Kirstjen Nielsen says surge in families claiming asylum is set to overwhelm system entirely. WASHINGTON-Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen told Congress Wednesday that the U.S. faces a "real, serious and sustained crisis at our borders" and defended President Trump's declaration of a national emergency to obtain more funds for border barriers.

title: Auditors Worry Boards Aren't Getting Good Information on Risks
summary: Directors often don't verify information they receive from management with internal auditors, according to a recent survey. Corporate boards may be overlooking critical information about emerging risks-in areas such as cybersecurity or workplace sexual harassment-by relying too heavily on information they receive from management, according to a recent survey of internal auditors.

title: Gray Wolves to Lose Endangered Species Protection Under Trump Administration Proposal
summary: Proponents say the species has rebounded after 45 years of government support and threatens cattle herds, but environmentalists disagree. The Trump administration is moving to delist the gray wolf from Endangered Species Act protections in the Lower 48 states, setting the stage for another potential clash over environmental policies with green groups and Democrats in Congress.

title: Amazon to Shut Its U.S. Pop-Up Stores Amid Strategy Shift
summary: Retail giant to close 87 pop-up locations, ending yearslong experiment by late April. Amazon.com Inc. is shutting down all 87 of its U.S. pop-up stores, ending the retailer's yearslong experiment with these small shops as the company tinkers with an evolving bricks-and-mortar strategy.

title: Startup Stock Exchange Builds Executive Team With Nasdaq Hires
summary: Wall Street-backed MEMX plans to launch a low-cost stock exchange.

title: Murphy Wants to Hold Off on NJ Transit Fare Hikes for Second Year
summary: Governor's plan would still increase funding for struggling state rail and bus system. New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy said Wednesday that he hopes to freeze NJ Transit fares for a second year in a row while increasing funding for the struggling statewide rail and bus system.

title: U.S. Government-Bond Prices Follow European Debt Higher
summary: Traders bet on European Central Bank deploying further stimulus. U.S. government-bond prices rose Wednesday, following a rally in eurozone debt as traders bet on the European Central Bank deploying further stimulus to perk up the economy.

title: Russian Linked to Manafort Is a Shadowy Presence
summary: Onetime colleague of Paul Manafort who authorities say is connected to Russian intelligence could be a factor as the former Trump campaign manager is sentenced Thursday. Special counsel Robert Mueller has accused Konstantin Kilimnik of having "ties to Russian intelligence," while a federal judge has described this allegation as an "undisputed core" of Mr. Mueller's probe into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: As Talks Stall, North Korea Bolsters Its Nuclear Program
summary: Kim Jong Un is positioned to bolster his arsenal after talks stall. SEOUL-Meeting with Kim Jong Un in Hanoi last week, President Trump stressed he was in no rush for the North Korean leader to denuclearize provided the regime doesn't resume testing of missiles or nuclear weapons.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Decline on Inventories, Trade Deficit
summary: Domestic crude stockpiles jumped 7.1 million barrels last week. •U.S. benchmark oil prices declined Wednesday after a pair of bearish reports out of Washington, one showing a large rise in domestic inventories of crude oil, and another showing the U.S. trade deficit hit a 10-year high.

title: Hard-Line Cleric to Head Iran's Judiciary
summary: The appointment illustrates the enduring marginalization of Iranian reformists pushing for an overhaul of the judicial system and protection of human rights. BEIRUT-An Iranian cleric known for his role in condemning thousands of political prisoners to death in the 1980s will take leadership of Iran's powerful judiciary this week, in a move that is expected to keep the post under the influence of hard-liners.

title: A Ski and Spa Getaway That's a Trip Back in Time
summary: This classic luxury spa hotel in the Austrian Alps is as charmingly old-fashioned as it gets, from fondue feasts to toboggan rides. IS IT YOUR FIRST visit to the hotel?" said a well-groomed man, towel loosely draped over his loins. The man, who appeared to be in his mid-60s, hadn't broken a sweat; but he had broken the sauna's silence. Given that my wife and I were also basically naked, it sounded not unlike a pickup line. A perceptive one: It was indeed our first day at the Jagdhof Spa Hotel in Neustift, Austria, when we found our way to the Wilderer sauna-one of 20 different "bathing experiences" in Vitality World, the Jagdhof's vast spa complex. The man informed us he was from Belgium and had been returning to the hotel every winter for the past 16 years. "Now I am here with my grandchildren." he said, proudly. We soon understood why he kept coming back.

title: Fed's Beige Book: Shutdown Slowed Economic Activity in Some Areas
summary: Ten of the Fed's 12 regional districts reported economic output expanded at a 'slight-to-moderate' pace in recent weeks. WASHINGTON-Economic activity expanded across the U.S. at the beginning of 2019, with many parts of the country noting the government shutdown led to slower economic activity, according to a Federal Reserve report released Wednesday.

title: India Wants Facebook to Curb Fake News Ahead of Elections
summary: Panel asks for social network, along with WhatsApp and Instagram, to tighten controls before polls that could start as soon as this month. NEW DELHI-India is pushing Facebook Inc. to do more to combat fake news ahead of coming national elections, underscoring global scrutiny on the social-media titan.

title: Former Congressman Agrees to Repay Funds
summary: Prosecutors will drop corruption charges if Aaron Schock returns nearly $68,000 to his campaign committees and pays taxes he owes. CHICAGO-Former Rep. Aaron Schock of Illinois has agreed to repay tens of thousands of dollars in taxes and to campaign committees in exchange for prosecutors dismissing his felony corruption case.

title: Advance Publications to Buy Plagiarism-Scanning Company Turnitin for Nearly $1.75 Billion
summary: Move furthers Advance's expansion beyond its core print media market. Advance Publications Inc. agreed to acquire Turnitin, the software company that allows teachers to check whether papers submitted by students have been plagiarized, for nearly $1.75 billion, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Snapping Corporate America's Gender Problem
summary: Companies with gender diversity among senior management perform better, data shows. A female global director at a Fortune 500 company recently was giving the keynote address at a health-care conference and was asked by a male executive where the restrooms were. He assumed she was hotel staff.

title: It Is Prime Time for Smartwatches
summary: Once-expensive gimmicks are no longer a fad, but there is still plenty of market to reach. Smartwatches are most certainly no longer a fad. Whether their makers can turn them into necessities is the new billion-dollar question. Many billions of dollars, in fact.

title: Can the World's Wealthiest Absorb the High-End Home Glut?
summary: Despite a darkening economic climate, the richest expect to continue to get richer, with confidence highest in the U.S.. In Manhattan, there are around 500 homes asking $10 million and up, and a surfeit of mega-pricey properties is also appearing in Los Angeles and Miami. The growing glut of wildly expensive homes begs the question: Are there enough people who can afford them?

summary: General Electric's coming seminar evokes Vietnam-era campus activism. Hey hey, ho ho, these actuarial tables have got to go!

title: The Real Reason the Unemployment Rate Isn't Lower
summary: Disagreement between two main surveys suggests likelihood of sharp drop in unemployment, which could spur Fed hawkishness. A curious thing has happened in the job market since the end of 2017: Even as the economy added millions of jobs, the unemployment rate has barely budged, falling from 4.1% to 4%.

title: Sudanese Press for Change, Putting U.S.'s Embrace of Despot Under Scrutiny
summary: U.S. and Europe have supported Sudanese leader amid push to stem migration and stop terrorism. A bloody uprising against Sudanese President Omar al-Bashir is putting Western and Arab powers in an awkward spot: Few are ready to ditch the long-ruling despot, but they aren't prepared to support him, either.

title: Backstage Selfies With the Backstreet Boys or Bhad Bhabie
summary: VIP upgrades allow both superstars and indie music acts to earn higher revenues on tour.

title: From Climbing Wall to Real Mountain: Can You Handle It?
summary: A trio of documentaries have inspired climbers used to the controlled settings of a gym to scale actual cliff faces. Here how to get started. ALEX HONNOLD is alive. Which shouldn't be noteworthy except that a particular scene in "Free Solo," a documentary following his efforts to ropelessly scale the 3,000-foot face of Yosemite's El Capitan, clearly suggested that his death was about to be captured on film.

title: Heathrow Sells Debt to Allay Concerns Over Brexit
summary: Bond sales by U.K.-based companies have declined sharply ahead of the coming Brexit deadline. Europe's busiest airport raised €650 million ($735.4 million) from investors Wednesday amid concerns about how Brexit might affect the company's credit rating.

summary: Value investors piled into GE in the fourth quarter, potentially giving new CEO a steadier support base. For the newest investors in General Electric Co. , the proof is in the $21 billion biotechnology deal.

title: Dollar Tree to Close or Rebrand Nearly 600 Family Dollar Stores
summary: Retailer posts $2.73 billion goodwill-impairment charge against value of Family Dollar chain. Dollar Tree Inc. sharply marked down the value of its Family Dollar chain and announced plans to close hundreds of Family Dollar stores this year as the retailer struggles with a business it acquired over three years ago.

title: Bank of Canada Holds Key Rate at 1.75%
summary: Central bank strikes more cautious tone on future rate rises, cites weaker economic outlook. OTTAWA-The Bank of Canada held its key interest rate steady at 1.75% Wednesday as weaker global and domestic growth prospects prompted policy makers to express more caution about the pace of future rate increases.

title: Marie Kondo Isn't Sparking Joy for Thrift Stores
summary: A global 'Tidying Up' frenzy is burying donation centers with goods that truly, nobody wants. "We aren't a place for people to just dump their rubbish.". On a recent gray day, Ann Curtis loaded up the back of her station wagon with bric-a-brac, eager to reclaim her house after the youngest of her three daughters left for college. "I'm smitten with the Kondo bug," she said, referring to the decluttering guru Marie Kondo. "I'm desperate to get in the loft, the shed, the garage and sort, sort, sort."

title: Tesla Faces Backlash in China After Price Cuts
summary: Unhappy customers threaten Tesla's image in China as it prepares to build Shanghai factory; 'I feel like I wasted my money,' a Model X owner said. SHANGHAI- Tesla Inc. faces criticisms from Chinese customers complaining that they ended up paying thousands of dollars more for their new cars because they bought before the company's recently enacted price cuts.

title: Senators Propose Repeal of 1991, 2002 Mideast War Authorizations
summary: Bipartisan pair cite need to rein in president on use of force, reassert congressional power. WASHINGTON-A bipartisan pair of senators introduced legislation Wednesday repealing decades-old resolutions that authorized the use of military force for the Gulf and Iraq wars, the latest bid by lawmakers to reassert Congress's role in shaping foreign policy.

title: States Propose Increased Teacher Pay After Months Filled With Protests
summary: In the wake of strikes, both Democrat- and Republican-dominated states look at measures to raise teacher salaries. Governors and legislators in at least 25 states are proposing increasing teacher pay following strikes that crippled school operations and left hundreds of thousands of students missing school in recent months.

title: For Teens, a Push for Confidential Medical Advice
summary: Private conversations with doctors are more important as younger patients grapple with sensitive health issues from vaping to depression to birth control, experts and doctors say. When Hannah Regan was about 14 years old, her family doctor in Kentucky started a new routine. During checkups, the doctor would ask Hannah's mother to briefly step out of the exam room. Then, in private, Hannah would discuss a questionnaire she filled out about smoking, drinking, mental health and other sensitive issues. There were awkward moments, she says, but she appreciated the time alone with her doctor.

title: Videogame Experience Plays Well on Résumés
summary: Hiring managers are opening up to candidates who tout skills gained from making or playing videogames. Work history, check. Education, check. Videogame experience ... check?

summary: Resume Subscription. Select two schools from the full list of nearly 1,000 U.S. colleges and universities and compare how they stack up side-by-side.

summary: Gone are the days when sellers were in the driver's seat. Now, it's the buyers who are in control, and they are looking for deals..

title: 'Assad or We Burn the Country': How the Syrian Regime Prevailed
summary: Resume Subscription. Before the phrase was spray-painted on walls and stenciled on cars, Syrian military officers heard it in meetings to discuss how to quell an antigovernment uprising sweeping Syria in 2011.

title: North Korean Missile Launch Site Is Being Built Back Up Again
summary: Disclosure comes in the wake of failed U.S.-North Korean summit in Hanoi last week. North Korea is restoring a missile launch site it previously claimed to be dismantling as an overture to the U.S., according to newly released commercial satellite photos and people briefed on South Korean intelligence.

title: Russia Seizes Property From Jehovah's Witnesses After Ban
summary: Action follows imprisonment of Danish Jehovah's Witness and allegations that group's members have been detained and tortured. MOSCOW-Russian authorities have confiscated millions of dollars' worth of property from Jehovah's Witness organizations, in a move that raises concern the group is under deepening persecution despite assurances from the Kremlin that the faith isn't being targeted.

title: Trump Has Lots of Fans in Venezuela
summary: 'He's really the only one doing something for Venezuela,' says an accountant; antigovernment protesters sport Trump masks. CARACAS, Venezuela-President Trump's trade and other foreign policies have made him unpopular in many countries that are traditionally U.S. allies. But they love him in Venezuela.

title: Do Stars Really Have Points?
summary: We think stars are spiky because of technology: It's how they appear when their light is diffracted through a camera aperture.. A star-filled night sky is a vast and majestic sight, but its constancy and familiarity can also be comforting. Whether it is the best or worst day of your life, you can look upward and see the same stunning cosmos as every other human who has ever lived. I was thinking about this recently as I passed a shop window decorated with constellations of silver and gold paper stars. It brought me to a temporary standstill, because it occurred to me that, in fact, the way we think about the shape of stars has changed over the past few centuries, and the evidence was right there in the window.

title: The Trouble With Taxing Wealth
summary: Elizabeth Warren's proposed tax on net worth seems like a nearly surgical strike at inequality, but it may not be efficient. Around the world, governments in recent decades have sought to lighten the burden on capital by reducing taxes on dividends, capital gains, corporate profits and wealth. The motivation is straightforward: more capital means more investment, higher productivity and faster growing wages. Capital is also highly mobile: Tax it too much, and it will go elsewhere, undermining growth.

title: Before You Buy Plane Tickets, Remember These Four Things
summary: When to buy, which way to fly and other money-saving travel tips for airline travel. Just when you thought you had airlines figured out, new research shows changes in carriers' pricing strategy that shred some long-held ticket-shopping beliefs and open new ways to save money.

title: Stocks to Watch: Ross, Urban Outfitters, AeroVironment, GE
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Wednesday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: U.S. Private Sector Adds 183,000 Jobs in February
summary: Most of jobs added were in service sector; with medium-size businesses posting strongest growth. The U.S. private sector added 183,000 jobs in February, according to a report released Wednesday, although the gains were smaller than expected as job creation slowed from a strong performance in January.

title: Group That Stole Singapore Health Records Persistently Attacked Country
summary: Method and targets indicate attacker was after information that would benefit an intelligence-gathering operation. SINGAPORE-A hacking group behind the theft of millions of health records in Singapore had persistently attacked organizations in the city-state, targeting industries including media, telecommunications, defense and energy, a cybersecurity company said.

title: Isabelle Huppert, Alex Katz, Nancy Silverton and More on Simplicity
summary: WSJ. asks six luminaries to weigh in on a single topic. This month: Simplicity. "Simplicity is a kind of compromise with everyday life. It's a way to put aside ambiguities and complexities to make life a little easier sometimes. I think of it almost as a philosophical attitude, but it doesn't mean that I practice it every second of my life. Instead, it's a purpose that I follow and a value that I cherish, whether it's in human relationships or acting. Acting is always very simple for me. Maybe it's because I have such an appetite for it. I guess for somebody else it could be difficult. Of course, that doesn't mean the roles are simple; and you don't arrive at that simplicity without a lot of conditions. You have to pull a thread between yourself and the final delivery of your performance. Even in the relationship with the director, I like simplicity. I like for things to be easy-I don't like conflict."

title: A Day in the Life of Everlane CEO Michael Preysman
summary: The forward thinker envisions a plastic-free future for his company-and the retail industry. Michael Preysman, founder and CEO of Everlane, the San Francisco-based brand known for $100 cashmere and transparent pricing, attended the same Cupertino high school as Steve Jobs. In his free time he picked berries and foraged for mushrooms with his parents and brother. Given his only-in-Northern-California upbringing, it may seem natural that decades later Preysman, 33, would start a company focused on innovation and environmentalism, but it wasn't part of his grand plan. "I thought I wanted to end up in private equity," says Preysman, who graduated with degrees in economics and computer engineering from Carnegie Mellon University in 2007. For three years after college he worked at the now shuttered investment fund Elevation Partners, spending the majority of that time in New York. But Preysman missed the West Coast, so he flew home to San Francisco and, with $1 million in seed funding, launched Everlane in 2011.

title: China Hits Off Switch on Laser Stock Beloved by Foreigners
summary: China bars foreigners from buying more shares in Han's Laser. China has barred foreigners from buying more shares in a Shenzhen-listed laser specialist, after global investors got close to breaching the country's 30% cap on international ownership for any single stock.

title: Tracking Michael Preysman
summary: A Day in the Life of Everlane CEO. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Mega-Contracts for Mega-Clients Drive Aon's Urge to Merge
summary: The brokerage may have dropped its bid for Willis Towers Watson, but look at the wider economy to see why it could return. To remain independent in corporate deal making, it helps to get your defense out early-especially when the unwanted suitor is proposing an all-share takeover.

title: MoviePass Tries to Reboot
summary: Subscription service to work closely with its parent company's film-production unit. Movie-subscription service MoviePass says it is revamping its business model after a tumultuous year.

title: U.S., China Face Off Over Digital-Market Regulation
summary: Some WTO members are pushing for sweeping digital trade rules, but international tensions present a hurdle. World Trade Organization members launched talks Wednesday on how to govern global digital commerce, for the first time tackling 21st century trade issues that have sparked intense rivalry among the U.S., Europe and China.

title: Snap Paid Settlements to Women Who Alleged Discrimination
summary: Staffers said workforce cuts targeted women unfairly; company later took steps to improve its culture and diversity. Snap Inc. last year paid settlements to at least three female employees who were let go in layoffs that they alleged disproportionately targeted women, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'La Tortuga' Is Here to Save Baseball
summary: The Twins' Willians Astudillo, nicknamed 'The Turtle,' has emerged as a fan favorite-with his everyman looks and carefree attitude. FORT MYERS, Fla.-It's no secret that baseball's grip on the collective imagination of the country has slipped. Football is the national sport now. Basketball is king with the social-media generation. Though America's pastime isn't dying, the long-term trend lines are worrisome.

title: Carlos Ghosn, Dressed as a Workman, Leaves Tokyo Jail on Bail After 108-Day Detention
summary: Former Nissan chairman is released after paying a bail of nearly $9 million. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn was freed Wednesday after what he called a "terrible ordeal" of 108 days behind bars, leaving a Tokyo jail disguised as a workman in a blue cap.

title: Qualcomm Cites National Security Risk in Bid to Settle FTC Case
summary: Defense and Energy Department officials lend support, saying Huawei stands to gain from a Qualcomm loss. WASHINGTON- Qualcomm Inc. is contending that U.S. national security could be undermined by a Federal Trade Commission case challenging the patent-royalty fees it charges for smartphones-and it is getting an assist from some federal officials.

title: Ghosn's 108 Days Behind Bars
summary: Carlos Ghosn left a detention center in Tokyo, dressed as a workman, and encountered a horde of media. He was released on $9 million bail as he awaits trial.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Mobile Ads Do More Work in One Second Than You Might Think
summary: Industry standards for 'ad viewability' overshadow what happens in the blink of an eye. Mobile advertisements begin triggering reactions in less than a second, new research suggests, leading some brands to re-examine their creative strategies as well as the industry's emphasis on longer exposures.

title: HNA Plans to Drop Defamation Suit Against Exiled Businessman Guo Wengui
summary: HNA's lawyers said the company concluded the lawsuit 'unnecessarily distracts from its key business priorities'. Chinese conglomerate HNA Group Co. told a court it plans to drop a defamation lawsuit against an exiled Chinese businessman living in New York, saying the complaint is now a distraction.

title: Silicon Valley Hit With New Digital Tax in France
summary: The 3% tax is aimed in part to give France leverage in global talks to update the corporate tax system. The French government on Wednesday introduced a new levy aimed at big tech businesses, adding to more than a dozen similar measures globally that collectively could cost Silicon Valley companies billions of dollars.

title: U.S.-China Trade Deal Expected to Give Limited Boost to Growth
summary: In its quarterly report, OECD cuts growth forecasts for the global economy. The global economy is unlikely to receive a big boost from a trade agreement between the U.S. and China, since it would likely leave much uncertainty over future economic relations between the two, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Wednesday.

title: Sony Made $250 Million Bet on Michael Jackson Before Documentary
summary: HBO's 'Leaving Neverland' could complicate effort to profit from music distribution deal. Sony Music Entertainment last year entered a deal worth $250 million for the rights to distribute Michael Jackson's recordings for seven more years, according to a person familiar with the matter. That investment looks riskier following a new documentary accusing the late pop star of sexually abusing young boys.

title: Uber Partner Picks Up $1.5 Billion From SoftBank
summary: Southeast Asian ride-hailing company Grab has raised a total of $4.5 billion in latest fundraising round. SINGAPORE-Southeast Asian ride-hailing company Grab Holdings Inc. has raised $1.46 billion in fresh funding from Japan's SoftBank Group Corp. , which it will use to fuel its expansion beyond transportation services.

title: China's Tesla Is Looking Less Electric
summary: Resume Subscription. Chinese electric-vehicle maker NIO Inc. has got investors all revved up lately. Its latest dismal outlook should instill a sense of reality.

title: Nintendo to Smartphone Gamers: Don't Spend Too Much on Us
summary: Users can pay for enhancements to speed up game play but company doesn't want them to shell out too much. TOKYO-Smartphone game makers working with Nintendo Co. are finding the home of Mario the plumber is putting up obstacles to scoring high revenue.

title: Surging Foreign Activity in Chinese Stocks Will Test Beijing
summary: A trading link with Hong Kong is enabling ever higher foreign ownership of Chinese shares. Its growing success will pose more questions about how it operates.. All roads are currently headed north when it comes to Chinese stocks. Overseas investors have been piling into mainland shares in recent days using the Stock Connect trading link with Hong Kong, taking trading volumes via the system to their highest level since it launched just over four years ago. Further growth, though, won't be pain-free.

title: Chinese Market Rally Helps Trim One Source of Financial Risk
summary: Resume Subscription. A surging stock market and Beijing's support have helped reduce one vulnerability in China's financial system: widespread borrowing by entrepreneurs against their shareholdings.

title: Glynn's Take: RBA Deeply Puzzled by Growth Slump
summary: In November the RBA had made a confident prediction that the economy would grow by a blistering 3.25% in 2018. SYDNEY-Deeply puzzled is one way to describe the mood at the Reserve Bank of Australia, after news the economy barely registered a pulse in the final months of 2018.

title: Carlos Ghosn Pays Bail of Nearly $9 Million; Release Is Imminent
summary: Ghosn's wife earlier visited him at the Tokyo Detention House. TOKYO-Carlos Ghosn paid bail of nearly $9 million on Wednesday and was set to leave a Tokyo jail shortly, ending a confinement that lasted 108 days.

title: Qatar to Sell Dollar Bonds for Second Straight Year
summary: The tiny emirate is joining the rush of emerging markets borrowing from yield-hungry investors. Qatar plans to tap the dollar-bond market for the second year in a row, adding to the rush of emerging markets borrowing from yield-hungry investors.

title: FDA Approves Controversial Drug for Depression
summary: Nasal spray branded Spravato by manufacturer Johnson & Johnson is close chemical relation to ketamine. The Food and Drug Administration approved a controversial drug for depression Tuesday that could be the first of a long-awaited wave of new treatments, but has also raised concerns about abuse.

title: Limits on Wall Street Pay Are Back on Regulators' Agenda
summary: Some bank executives are open to new rules, hoping for softer pay limits now than if a Democrat becomes president in 2020. WASHINGTON-Long-dormant efforts to restrict Wall Street pay are back on the agenda as regulators turn to unfinished business left over from the 2010 financial overhaul.

title: Trump, Allies Attack House Probes as 'Fishing Expedition'
summary: Democrats have sent document requests to more than 80 organizations and Trump associates. WASHINGTON-President Trump and close congressional allies on Tuesday denounced the investigations by House Democrats into possible obstruction of justice, abuse of power and corruption, which Mr. Trump labeled a "big, fat, fishing expedition."

title: Trump to Nominate Jessie Liu as Justice Department's No. 3 Official
summary: Search for a new associate attorney general has taken a year after several previous candidates didn't pan out. WASHINGTON-President Trump said he would nominate federal prosecutor Jessie Liu as the Justice Department's No. 3 official, after a year in which his administration failed to persuade several candidates to take on the challenging position.

title: House to Vote on Measure Condemning Anti-Semitism, in Implicit Rebuke to Freshman Democrat
summary: Rep. Ilhan Omar's criticism of U.S. policy toward Israel has prompted accusations of anti-Semitism. WASHINGTON-The House of Representatives is set to vote as early as Thursday on a Democratic resolution condemning anti-Semitism, an implicit rebuke to a freshman lawmaker whose criticism of U.S. policy toward Israel has prompted accusations of anti-Semitism.

title: China Restricts Canadian Grain Processor
summary: Canola imports from Richardson International are barred by Beijing as Huawei dispute simmers. OTTAWA-China has banned canola imports from the largest Canadian-owned grain processor, at a time of escalating diplomatic tensions fueled by the arrest of Huawei Technologies Co.'s chief financial officer.

title: New York, Beijing Chip Away at Silicon Valley
summary: Growth of digital tools at companies world-wide is set to unseat the world's go-to technology hub, a KPMG survey finds. Amazon.com Inc. may have dropped plans to build a campus in New York, but many technology industry leaders say the city is on track to become a go-to innovation source for businesses world-wide in the next few years, according to a study by KPMG LLP.

title: Trump Orders Creation of Task Force Addressing Veteran Suicide
summary: Effort will be directed by Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie. WASHINGTON-President Trump signed an executive order Tuesday creating a cabinet-level task force addressing veteran suicide, to be directed by Secretary of Veterans Affairs Robert Wilkie.

title: Bail for Ghosn-but Justice?
summary: Prosecutors in Japan held him for months. Where's their case?. Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan CEO arrested at a Tokyo airport last November, is finally being released on $9 million in bail. It's a step forward for the Japanese legal proceeding-such as it is-even if it comes with onerous terms. Twice Mr. Ghosn's bail requests were denied, until a new lawyer proposed he would live under surveillance and with restrictions on his phone and computer use.

title: Nadler's 'Obstruction' Quest
summary: The examples he cites as crimes are legal presidential actions.. Well, we're off on the march to impeachment, as we predicted last year even as Democrats said it wasn't on their minds. With Chairman Jerry Nadler's subpoena swarm from House Judiciary this week, and his assertions that President Trump obstructed justice, the articles of impeachment are apparently awaiting only the collection of the readily available details to fill in the blanks.

title: The Duty of the Free Press
summary: 'How is the media helping American democracy? How it is hurting?' Students respond.. Editor's note: In this Future View, students write about the media. Next week's question centers on the $1.5 trillion Americans owe in student debt. We'll ask, "How have student loans changed your plans for the future?" Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before March 12. The best responses will be published that night.

title: 'Oklahoma!' Takes Aim at Gun Issue
summary: The revival will be the first Broadway show to join a new gun-related initiative that aims to mitigate the depiction of gun violence. When the revival of "Oklahoma!" arrives on Broadway this month, it will bring to life the classic 1943 Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, replete with rough-and-tumble depictions of the American frontier. Naturally, that means the presence of prop guns throughout the show.

title: Mr. Chaos vs. The Swamp
summary: Without Russia collusion, Democrats have only hatred of Donald Trump.. In the small favors department, Donald Trump can be thankful for how his renegade lawyer Michael Cohen chose to oblige committee Democrats by fanning the dying embers of Russiagate.

title: Democrats Can't Dodge Foreign Policy
summary: Presidential hopefuls must explain how they'd restore U.S. strategy after Trump.. A presidential campaign is an audition for the most challenging job in the world. But the Democrats vying for their party's nomination don't seem to understand what that job really is. People with White House experience know that presidents spend more than half their time-often much more-dealing with foreign policy and national security. Thus far, Democratic candidates have had little to say about these issues.

title: Behind the Scenes at the Vatican
summary: I saw an apartment under renovation. The next day, the pope said he would resign.. As with many historic places, the Vatican is the site of weighty and ordinary events. I've been lucky enough to see both.

title: Confirmation Bias Hurts Social Science
summary: The debunking of an implausible study shows the need for viewpoint diversity in the academy.. Humility can be hard to come by in professional research, which is why it's worth noting the retraction last month of a major study on the social effects of attitudes toward sexuality. The journal Social Science & Medicine withdrew a 2014 analysis purporting to show that widespread traditional beliefs about sexual morality-or "structural stigma"-gravely imperil the health of people who don't identify as straight, whom the study classified as "sexual minorities." Lead author Mark Hatzenbuehler, a professor at Columbia's Mailman School of Public Health, is a renowned expert on stigma and health. The study has been widely reported and frequently cited.

title: Record Immigration Surge at the Border
summary: Numbers traveling in family groups since October exceeds record for a full, 12-month period. Arrests of families crossing the U.S.-Mexico border illegally in the past five months hit a record, prompting the chief of Customs and Border Protection to say the system is at "the breaking point."

title: 'Ten Drugs' Review: Better Living Through Chemistry
summary: All sorts of medicinal wonders have emerged from laboratories-and nature itself-with missteps and eureka moments along the way.. In an age of technological wonders, few can equal the life-altering and life-saving drugs that have poured forth from laboratories and research teams in the 20th and early 21st centuries. Anti-psychotic drugs have emptied mental hospitals. Antibiotics have added years to average life expectancy. Birth control pills have transformed sex lives-and mores. Seeming miracles can feel almost routine: Jimmy Carter, after being diagnosed with metastatic melanoma in 2015, took a recently approved drug called pembrolizumab, which redirected his immune system and played a decisive role in ridding him of cancer.

title: Democrats Hope Scandal Trumps Economic Growth in 2020
summary: Their agenda of nonstop investigations may keep the president unpopular, but can it defeat him?. Democrats have settled on a strategy for making Donald Trump a one-term president, and it amounts to rehashing last week's Michael Cohen fiasco over and over between now and November 2020.

title: The Logic of Trump's North Korea Approach
summary: He's wisely stuck with sanctions, and it isn't as if his predecessors ever had much success.. There is lots to criticize in President Donald Trump's North Korea policy. He sounds insensitive to the case of Otto Warmbier, displays more warmth toward Kim Jong Un than South Korea's leaders, depicts military exercises with the South as "very provocative" and exaggerates his progress. Yet there may be a method here.

title: FDA Chief Gottlieb to Leave Agency
summary: He sought to crack down on cigarette makers and accelerated some generic-drug approvals. Scott Gottlieb, who as head of the Food and Drug Administration sought to crack down on cigarette makers and speed the approval of generic medicines, is resigning from his post, the agency said.

title: Sincerely, Emmanuel
summary: Macron offers Europe an earnest recitation of his worst ideas.. As political campaign tactics go, we've seen better than the open letter that French President Emmanuel Macron sent this week laying out a pan-Europe agenda ahead of May's European Parliament elections. He manages to combine bad ideas with off-putting self-promotion.

title: Tornado-Torn Alabama Community Begins Long Haul of Rebuilding
summary: Mayor of Smiths Station estimates cleanup will take months. SMITHS STATION, Ala.-Two days after a tornado ripped through his small town, leaving as many as 70 families homeless, Mayor F.L. "Bubba" Copeland walked the debris-lined roads, hugging residents and dispatching volunteers to lift tree limbs off totaled cars and distribute donations.

title: Insurance Broker for Trump Businesses Subpoenaed
summary: Internal communications, documents sought by New York state regulator. A New York state financial regulator has asked the Trump Organization's longtime insurance broker for documents and internal communications pertaining to its dealings with President Trump's businesses, according to a person familiar with the matter.
